key_points: A federal grand jury in Minneapolis indicted four former police officers for federal civil rights crimes related to George Floyd's death.
Derek Chauvin is charged with violating George Floyd's right to be free from unreasonable force, resulting in bodily injury and death.
Tou Thao and J. Alexander Kueng are charged with failing to intervene to stop Chauvin's use of unreasonable force.
All four defendants are accused of willful indifference to Floyd's medical needs, violating his right to due process.
A separate indictment charges Chauvin with violating the constitutional rights of a 14-year-old in 2017, including the use of a flashlight as a dangerous weapon.
Both indictments allege violations under Title 18, United States Code, Section 242, concerning the willful violation of constitutional rights under color of law.
An indictment is a formal accusation, and the defendants are presumed innocent until proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.
These federal charges are separate from a civil pattern or practice investigation into the Minneapolis Police Department.
The federal charges announced are in addition to state charges related to Floyd's death, focusing on violations of the U.S. Constitution.
The cases are being prosecuted by a team from the District of Minnesota and the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice.
